plaintiff.name: Sarah Johnson
plaintiff.residency: State of New York, and New York County
plaintiff.consumer_status: Individual 'consumer' within the meaning of both the FCRA and the NY FCRA

defendants.name: FIRST NATIONAL BANK
defendants.business_status: Duly authorized and qualified to do business in the State of New York

factual_background.summary: Plaintiff is a victim of identity theft. While plaintiff was out of town, thieves used her First National Bank credit card to make over $3,200 in fraudulent purchases without her consent.

events.description: Plaintiff opened First National Bank credit card with $5,000 credit limit.
Identity theft occurred - fraudulent charges totaling $3,200.
Plaintiff disputed charges with bank on five separate occasions.
Bank refused to remove charges, claimed they were valid.
Plaintiff sent written disputes to all three credit reporting agencies.
All agencies responded that debt was 'verified as accurate'.

additional_notes: Bank told plaintiff 'the chip was used so charges must be valid'
Plaintiff was out of town when fraudulent charges occurred
Plaintiff has travel receipts proving she was in Boston during fraud period

causes_of_action.title: VIOLATION OF THE FCRA
allegations: Defendants Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion willfully (or, in the alternative, negligently) violated 15 U.S.C. ยง 1681i by failing to conduct reasonable reinvestigations...
Defendant First National Bank willfully (or, in the alternative, negligently) violated 15 U.S.C. ยง 1681s-2(b) by failing to conduct reasonable reinvestigations...

causes_of_action.title: VIOLATION OF THE NY FCRA
allegations: Defendants Experian, Equifax and TransUnion willfully (or, in the alternative, negligently) violated N.Y. GBL ยง 380-f by failing to conduct reasonable reinvestigations...

damages.summary: The erroneous derogatory payment information wrongfully listed on Plaintiff's consumer reports caused her to suffer actual damages including, but not limited to, damage to reputation, adverse impact on credit rating, being denied credit, in addition to emotional distress, expenditure of time and resources, annoyance, aggravation, and frustration.
